title: flat search + filter not working
body:
```
(Pdb) ds.to_table()
pyarrow.Table
vector: fixed_size_list<item: float>[2]
  child 0, item: float
item: string
price: double
----
vector: [[[3.1,4.1],[5.9,26.5]]]
item: [["foo","bar"]]
price: [[10,20]]
```

```
(Pdb) ds.to_table(filter="price < 15", nearest={"column": "vector", "q": [100., 100.], "k": 1})
pyarrow.Table
vector: fixed_size_list<item: float>[2]
  child 0, item: float
item: string
price: double
score: float not null
----
vector: [[[5.9,26.5]]]
item: [["bar"]]
price: [[20]]
score: [[14257.06]]
```

note that this is the flat KNN search. the expected result is empty row (post filtering)

title: Refactor / cleanup the calculation of positions

title: Bugfix for BinaryEncoder positions
body:
When merging multiple arrays, BinaryEncoder creates a array of positions/offsets that it is too big.

For instance in the following array:

```rust
&[
    &StringArray::from(vec![Some("a"), None, Some("cd"), None]),
    &StringArray::from(vec![Some("f"), None, Some("gh"), None]),
    &StringArray::from(vec![Some("t"), None, Some("uv"), None]),
]
```

Each sub-array has its own offset array. Since each array has 4 elements the offset array has 5 elements

```
offsets: [0, 1, 1, 3, 3]
offsets: [0, 1, 1, 3, 3]
offsets: [0, 1, 1, 3, 3]
```

When BinaryEncoder merge all sub-arrays into a single Array, it creates an array of length 12 (4*3) but an offset array with 15 elements

```
pos_array: PrimitiveArray<Int64>
[
  4,
  5,
  5,
  7,
  7,
  8,
  9,
  9,
  11,
  11,
  12,
  13,
  13,
  15,
  15,
]
```

This PR makes it create the correct offset array with 13 elements

```
pos_array: PrimitiveArray<Int64>
[
  4,
  5,
  5,
  7,
  7,
  8,
  8,
  10,
  10,
  11,
  11,
  13,
  13,
]
```

title: Filtering strings doesn't work
body:
Not quite clear to me how PyArrow Compute functions & Lance interweave. Should I be able to use any of them? Are they re-implemented in Lance?

Regardless, I'm just trying to do a a substring match:

```python
import lance
import numpy as np
import pyarrow.compute as pc

ds = lance.dataset("2.lance")
filters = pc.match_like(pc.field("title"), "%")
ds.to_table(filter=filters, nearest={"column": "vector", "q": np.random.random(768)})
```

Gets an errror like:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/chris/search/gumbase/experiments/test_lance_filters.py", line 7, in <module>
    ds.to_table(filter=filters, nearest={"column": "vector", "q": np.random.random(768)})
  File "/home/chris/.pyenv/versions/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lance/dataset.py", line 159, in to_table
    return self.scanner(
  File "/home/chris/.pyenv/versions/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lance/dataset.py", line 102, in scanner
    ScannerBuilder(self)
  File "/home/chris/.pyenv/versions/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lance/dataset.py", line 460, in to_scanner
    scanner = self.ds._ds.scanner(
ValueError: LanceError(I/O): sql parser error: Expected an expression:, found: {
```

title: Formalize io exec node contracts
body:
Currently there's no formal contract for the input/output of an exec node. This causes mismatches between node.schema and the schema of the record batches from the schema (because node.schema is not guaranteed to match output or the input).

An example of brittleness and hacks that we have to build in is in #686 

We should make it so that:
1. Each exec node declares it's output schema formally
2. Add unit tests to make sure the output schema is enforced
3. Add integration tests to make sure the possible IO plans are valid

title: Missing column when both `nearest` and `filter` are applied
body:
Addresses #685

- [x] reproduce issue
- [x] RCA => score column is missing due to incorrect projection when filters are present for ANN.
- [x] Fix

@eddyxu the fix is hacky due to the lack of formal contracts on the io exec nodes. That's why you see the weird `ann_schema` variable being passed to the local take node. Happy to walk through the logic with you over zoom if that's quicker.

title: Bug when specifying `nearest` and  `filters`
body:
Was trying to use the ANN search with prefilters:

```python
import lance
import numpy as np
import pyarrow.compute as pc

filters=pc.greater(pc.field('price'), 100.0)
ds = lance.dataset('2.lance')
ds.to_table(filter=filters, nearest={"column": "vector", "q":np.random.random(768)})
```

And I get the error:

```
File ~/.pyenv/versions/3.8.16/envs/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/lance/dataset.py:475, in LanceScanner.to_table(self)
    471 def to_table(self) -> pa.Table:
    472     """
    473     Read the data into memory and return a pyarrow Table.
    474     """
--> 475     return self.to_reader().read_all()

File ~/.pyenv/versions/3.8.16/envs/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyarrow/ipc.pxi:750, in pyarrow.lib.RecordBatchReader.read_all()

File ~/.pyenv/versions/3.8.16/envs/vector_search/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyarrow/error.pxi:100, in pyarrow.lib.check_status()

ArrowInvalid: ArrowArray struct has 14 children, expected 15 for type struct<product_id: int64, title: string, handle: string, image_id: double, image_url: string, price: double, shop_id: int64, shop_slug: string, country_code: string, currency_code: string, image: string, major_centroid_id: int64, __index_level_0__: int64, vector: fixed_size_list<item: float>[768], score: float not null>
```

title: streaming ivf training
body:
This PR samples the IVF input data in-stream during scan. Does not handle opq/pq kmeans yet. The complication here is that we need the sampled data for kmeans trainining and then to compute pq codes for all vectors we need an additional scan 

to avoid the higher order lifetime issue, i pass in the count_rows from the create_index call. I believe the closure makes it so the compiler can't prove the lifetimes here.

title: update arrow-rs version in duckdb-ext for lance as well
Fix flaky `test_versions` test
body:
`test_versions` in `test_dataset.py` is flaky. Sometime it fails with:

```
python/tests/test_dataset.py::test_versions FAILED                       [  9%]

=================================== FAILURES ===================================
________________________________ test_versions _________________________________

tmp_path = PosixPath('/tmp/pytest-of-runner/pytest-0/test_versions0')

    def test_versions(tmp_path: Path):
        table1 = pa.Table.from_pylist([{"a": 1, "b": 2}, {"a": 10, "b": 20}])
        base_dir = tmp_path / "test"
        lance.write_dataset(table1, base_dir)
    
        assert len(lance.dataset(base_dir).versions()) == 1
    
        table2 = pa.Table.from_pylist([{"s": "one"}, {"s": "two"}])
        time.sleep(1)
        lance.write_dataset(table2, base_dir, mode="overwrite")
    
        assert len(lance.dataset(base_dir).versions()) == 2
    
        v2, v1 = lance.dataset(base_dir).versions()
        assert isinstance(v1["timestamp"], datetime)
        assert isinstance(v2["timestamp"], datetime)
>       assert v1["timestamp"] < v2["timestamp"]
E       assert datetime.datetime(2023, 3, 8, 19, 2, 50, 956316) < datetime.datetime(2023, 3, 8, 19, 2, 49, 947502)

python/tests/test_dataset.py:58: AssertionError
============================= slowest 30 durations =============================
```

Look into why this happens. It is possible that we need to add an explicit sort on version number before returning in Rust to return versions in ascending order.

title: [DuckDB] Support export table from DuckDB to lance
body:
# Problem Statement

Duckdb allows to export a table via `COPY/EXPORT` command.

https://duckdb.org/docs/sql/statements/export.html
```sql
-- export the table contents with the given options
EXPORT DATABASE 'target_directory' (FORMAT CSV, DELIMITER '|');
-- export the table contents as parquet
EXPORT DATABASE 'target_directory' (FORMAT PARQUET);
```

# Desired Behavior

In Lance duckdb extension, we could support `COPY` statement

```
COPY (SELECT * FROM tbl) TO 'output.lance' (FORMAT LANCE);
```

title: Windows support
body: unix::read_at does not move files underlying cursor while window::seek_read does. If this is the only place file access actually happens this should be fine, because both methods take offsets relative to file, and don't care about cursor. If file access happens in other places this could be a potential footgun

A directory for Java/Scala

I propose to create a directory for Java/Scala interfaces, which includes:
* Rust code for make JNI compatible interfaces.
* Java code for JNI interfaces.
* Java code for minimal interfaces that let Java/Kotlin/Groovy users can work with, and we create Scala interface based on them.
* Scala code for expressive interfaces that let Spark users can work with.

How about name the directory with `jvm`?

title: [DuckDB] Support predicate pushdown via pyarrow dataset
body:
# Problem Statement

Allow the duckdb extension to pass the filters (predicates) to lance, so it gives lance a chance to optimize I/O exec plan.

```sql
SELECT col1, col2 FROM s3://bucket/path/foo.lance WHERE a > 1 AND b < 2
```

will essentially calls

```rust
Dataset.scanner(columns=["col1", "col2"], filter="a > 1 AND b < 2")
```

title: [DuckDB] Implement replacement scan function for Lance Scan in DuckDB
body:
# Problem Statement

DuckDB has a concept of `replacement scan` when the URL of dataset matches to certain pattern, the URL itself can be used to indicate which scan function to call, 

For example, 

```sql
SELECT * FROM s3://foo/bar/zoo.lance
-- Replace
SELECT * FROM lance_scan("s3://foo/bar/zoo.lance")
```

Reference of the old (c++) implementation

https://github.com/eto-ai/lance/blob/78e5af7dec1a9602823797ba18eafc632ba727c3/integration/duckdb/src/lance/duckdb/lance-extension.cc#L65

# Desired Behavior

Re-enable the scan replacement of lance scan in the rust-based duckdb extension.

title: [DuckDB] Expose vector search capability via duckdb extension
body:
# Problem Statement

Lance rust dataset has the capability of querying over vector space, via `Scannner::nearest(..)`, we should expose this to DuckDB via its extension mechanism.
For example, a potential implementation could be a duckdb table function `lance_nearest`

```sql
SELECT id, col 
FROM lance_nearest("table", "vector_column", "query", top_k)
WHERE city = 'SF' and day = "02-03-2023"
```

title: [Rust] Handle double equals in filter
body: `pyarrow.compute.Expression` will generate double equals as filters. Add support in the rust core to handle double eq `==`.

title: [Python] Allow user to bypass ANN index, and run flat ann (brute-force) instead.
body:
# Problem Statement

To debug the performance, sometimes we need to see what data is actually in a IVF partition. By bypassing the ann index, we can allow a knn query to bruth-forcely to compare against to all vectors in one partition, which gives us the ground truth for recall computations.

title: Scan node to detect channel close and gracefully break the scan.
Parsing pyarrow.compute.Expression
body:
The Rust sqlparser we're using cannot deal with:

- `==`, which is produced by equality in pc.Expression
- `isin`, which stringify's to some internal repr
- similarly other function calls supported by pyarrow compute

This is a blocker for exposing filter predicate pushdowns to python as pyarrow API

body: Currently the long pole on a lot of builds is the mac build on GHA. Regularly breaking the 30 min barrier. One way to shorten this substantially is to use GHA cache for homebrew. Perhaps something like https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-cask/actions/runs/4258015346/workflow

title: Optimize random reads over boolean array
body:
# Problem Statement

Currently, when we call `take(indices)` a boolean array, it reads the array from `indices[0]..indices[-1]`, when the indices are sparse, such read path is not optimial.

For example, if we want to read `indices=[1, 100000, 500000]`, the data buffer of [1..500000]` will be read, instead, we can just issue three small reads for 1, 100000, and 500000 respectively.

title: more unit tests for filter predicates
Relax data type matching float numbers in filter pushdown
Fix crash with column projection with ann search
python integration tests for vector index
expand tilde paths in python
body:
Resolves issue #619 . 

### Current behavior:
On Posix systems (tested on Mac), this creates a subdirectory in the current directory, instead of resolving to the user's home directory. 
```py
addr = "~/foo.lance"
df = pd.DataFrame({"colA": [1, 2, 3], "colB": [4, 5, 6]})
lance.write_dataset(df, addr)
```
At read time, it tries to read off the current directory again. 

### Expected behavior: 
Treat `~` prefix as pointing to the user's home directory. 

### Notes:
- The error is related to tilde expansion, which is really a bash feature. Python doesn't handle these by default either. 
```py
with open("~/moo.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("hello\n")

# FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '~/moo.txt'
```

- The PR uses a python stdlib function to handle expanding these paths. This is also used in pandas - [link](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/d08d4510db5e79b8e65b35174a3bc3a968bb9189/pandas/io/common.py#L183). 

- This can also be handled in rust but would require another third party dep - [link](https://crates.io/crates/expanduser/1.2.2).

title: Expose index stats for debugging
body:
we want to expose the vector index stats to the user (in python) for debugging purposes:

1. index name, id, and file location
2. index type
3. if ivf_pq: num ivf partitions, num pq sub vectors, num pq bits
4. if ivf_pq: for each partition, the centroid vector for the partition and the number of vectors in that partition.

on the python side, the api can look like:

`dataset.list_index` => [Index]

`dataset.get_index("name")` -> Index

Index should have:
- index_type
- name
- index-id
- uri

IvfPqIndex (subclass of Index) should have:
- num ivf partitions
- num pq sub vectors
- num pq bits
- each ivf centroid
- num vectors in in partition

title: workaround to prevent the segfault until we figure out the real problem

title: Improve random access on binary encoding
body: Closes #604

title: Dataset or TakeExec cache the opened fragment.
body:
# Problem Statement

When filter is provided, we will build an I/O execution plan like

```
LocalTakeExec() -> FilterExec() -> Scan()
```

To make the scan more efficient, the `LocalTakeExec` node should have maintain `FileReader` for the same file opened in Scan, so that `LakeTakeExec` node can do random access take without repeatedly open the same file.

In the previous C++ version, we had made the protocol between execution node to pass the batch id in `ScanBatch`

https://github.com/eto-ai/lance/blob/78e5af7dec1a9602823797ba18eafc632ba727c3/cpp/src/lance/io/exec/take.cc#L32

Which is challenging to implement in Rust and using Datafusion's physical execution plan.

# Desired Solution

When scanning a dataset with filter pushdown, `LocalTakeExec` does not need to repeatedly open new files.

title: Parse sql filter clause to create datafusion physical expression
Segfault when using f32
body:
When using a query vector that is 32bit I get a segfault in the following snippet:

```
    ds = dataset.to_table(
        nearest={
            "column": "vector",
            "q": query,
            "k": k,
            "nprobes": nprobe,
            "refine_factor": refine_factor,
        }
    )
```

Casting `query = query.astype(np.float64)` avoids the segfault. Probably worth implicitly casting or issuing a warning.

title: Add version tags
body:
Adds the ability to tag a Lance dataset and retrieve it from python. Per issue #588 

Notes
- This assumes different versions of the dataset can be given the same tag. And at fetch-time, we just return the latest one. Is this reasonable semantics? 
- Referencing the linked issue - is the version metadat (VersionAuxData in protobuf?) something that the users pass themselves, or something Lance creates? This PR just takes the tag as input from the user. 
- Introducing keyword-only arguments in the python api. 
This PR makes `asof` and `tag` as keyword-only args in the dataset read method. Might also want to do it for the `write_dataset` method for all args following the writing mode? It is getting crowded.
